title: OpenStack 29 Enhances AI, HPC Support; VMware Users Eye Shift to OpenInfra
post_content:
OpenStack: A Comprehensive Alternative for On-Premises Cloud Infrastructure

OpenStack has emerged as a leading open-source project for enterprises seeking to build and manage their own Amazon Web Services (AWS)-like private clouds. This week, the OpenInfra Foundation introduced the latest version, OpenStack 29, also known as 'Caracal.' This release focuses on enhancing features to accommodate artificial intelligence (AI) and high-performance computing (HPC) workloads.

Typical OpenStack users are large enterprise companies, including retailers like Walmart and telecommunication giants like NTT. With increasing interest in AI model deployment, businesses aim to maintain control over their entire stack while ensuring data security. OpenStack presents one of the few comprehensive alternatives to VMware's offerings, which have faced criticism since its acquisition by Broadcom. This situation has led many VMware users to explore alternatives, as OpenInfra Foundation executive director Jonathan Bryce noted, "With the Broadcom acquisition of VMware and some of the licensing changes they’ve made, we’ve had a lot of companies coming to us and taking another look at OpenStack."

OpenStack has experienced substantial growth, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, with South Korean cloud provider Okestro, a new Platinum Member of the OpenInfra Foundation, focusing heavily on AI. Europe, with its strong data sovereignty laws, is another growth market, as evidenced by the UK's Dawn AI supercomputer, which runs OpenStack. OpenInfra Foundation COO Mark Collier shared his excitement with TechCrunch, stating, "All the things are lining up for a big upswing and open-source adoption for infrastructure... So it’s pretty exciting to see another wave of infrastructure upgrades give our community some important work to complete for many years to come."

Notable features of OpenStack 29 include support for vGPU live migrations in Nova, the core compute service. This enhancement enables users to move GPU workloads from one physical server to another with minimal impact on the workloads. Additionally, this release includes security enhancements, such as rule-based access control for core OpenStack services like the Ironic bare-metal-as-a-service project, and networking updates to better support HPC workloads.

The Future of Net Neutrality: A Tale of Two Presidencies

The battle for net neutrality, a concept that has been weaving in and out of the shadows of federal protection for years, now stands at the precipice of either becoming enshrined in law or vanishing into oblivion. The outcome hinges heavily on the results of the impending election in November. In this blog post, we will delve into the two possible futures for net neutrality, the best-case scenario under a Biden administration, and the potential demise under a second Trump presidency.

Net neutrality is the principle that internet service providers (ISPs) must treat all online traffic equally, without any preferential deals, prioritization, throttling, or blocking (yes, even the cat videos). This principle, while largely technical in nature, has become a partisan lightning rod in recent years.

Under a Biden Presidency: A fragile victory

If the Democrats secure both the presidency and control of Congress, net neutrality is likely to see new life. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has expressed its intention to reestablish net neutrality rules, similar to those from 2015 but updated to overcome previous legal obstacles. A Notice of Proposed Rulemaking is set to be voted on later this month, with its passage being all but assured due to the current FCC makeup.

Once implemented, these rules would prevent ISPs from tampering with online traffic. A legislative effort may then follow, modifying the Communications Act that grants the FCC its power, potentially incorporating some aspects of the net neutrality rule. This could be accomplished alongside reforming Section 230 or other political bargaining chips.

But this victory is fragile and could easily be undone by a second Trump presidency or the Supreme Court's potential ruling on the Relentless case, which could significantly diminish the power of independent agencies like the FCC.

The Dark Ages: Net neutrality under a second Trump presidency

If Trump were to win reelection, net neutrality would face several threats. One of the most immediate dangers would be the appointment of a new FCC Chair, who would likely seek to repeal the net neutrality rules once again. These complex descriptions were then translated into behavioral strategies by asking the LLM whether it would cooperate or defect when it had such a personality trait.

Title: A Revolutionary Miniature Ionizer for Affordable In-Home Mass Spectrometry

Introduction

Mass spectrometry, a technique that can identify the chemical components of a sample with precision, has the potential to revolutionize health monitoring for chronic illness patients. Currently, mass spectrometers are expensive and typically confined to laboratories, which makes managing chronic diseases more challenging due to the need for blood samples to be sent for testing. Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) are working on developing a solution to make mass spectrometry local and accessible for at-home use. They have designed and 3D printed a low-cost ionizer, a critical component of mass spectrometers, which outperforms its state-of-the-art counterparts.

The Challenge: High Cost and Limited Accessibility of Mass Spectrometers

Mass spectrometers can be prohibitively expensive, costing several hundred thousand dollars, making them inaccessible for many individuals and healthcare facilities. Moreover, these machines are typically found in laboratories, necessitating the sending of blood samples for testing, which can be an inefficient and time-consuming process for chronic disease management.

The Vision: Local and Affordable Mass Spectrometry

Luis Fernando Velásquez-García, a principal research scientist in MIT's Microsystems Technology Laboratories (MTL), envisions a future where mass spectrometry is accessible and local, enabling people with chronic diseases to monitor their health from the comfort of their homes. For this vision to become a reality, the hardware must be inexpensive and easily producible.

The Breakthrough: A 3D Printed Low-Cost Ionizer

Velásquez-García and his team have developed a low-cost ionizer using 3D printing technology, which performs twice as well as its state-of-the-art counterparts. This miniature ionizer, only a few centimeters in size, can be manufactured at scale, making it more cost-effective than traditional ionizers. By 3D printing the device, the researchers can precisely control its shape and utilize special materials that enhance its performance, ultimately producing an ionizer that works better than those made using expensive processes and specialized instruments.

title: 3D Magnetic Recording Breakthrough: Boosting Hard Drive Capacity and Energy Efficiency
post_content:
Title: A Breakthrough in Data Storage: The Emergence of 3D Magnetic Recording

In the ever-evolving world of data storage, research groups from NIMS, Seagate Technology, and Tohoku University have made a significant breakthrough. They have demonstrated the feasibility of multi-level recording using a three-dimensional magnetic recording medium, paving the way for increased storage capacity and cost-effective solutions in hard disk drives (HDDs).

At present, data centers store vast amounts of data on HDDs equipped with perpendicular magnetic recording (PMR). With areal densities of approximately 1.5 Tbit/in2, PMR technology has been the go-to method for data storage. However, to transition to higher areal densities, a high anisotropy magnetic recording medium with FePt grains combined with heat-assisted laser writing is required. This method, known as heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), can sustain areal recording densities of up to 10 Tbit/in2.

In a recent study published in Acta Materialia, the team successfully arranged FePt recording layers three-dimensionally. By fabricating lattice-matched, FePt/Ru/FePt multilayer films, with Ru as a spacer layer, they achieved a significant milestone. Measurements of the magnetization reveal that the two FePt layers have different Curie temperatures, which makes three-dimensional recording possible by adjusting the laser power when writing.

The researchers also demonstrated the principle of 3D recording through recording simulations. By using a media model that mirrors the microstructure and magnetic properties of the fabricated media, they showed that multi-level recording is, indeed, achievable in a three-dimensional magnetic recording medium.

The three-dimensional magnetic recording method has the potential to revolutionize the data storage landscape. By stacking recording layers in three dimensions, more digital information can be stored with fewer HDDs. This leads to energy savings for data centers, as well as a more efficient and cost-effective approach to data storage.

On Thursday, Reuters reported that Alphabet, Google's parent company, is contemplating the acquisition of Boston-based HubSpot, a customer relationship management (CRM) and marketing automation powerhouse, currently valued at over $33 billion. This article will delve into the implications of this potential deal, its likelihood, and the benefits for both parties.

The reported acquisition cost would undoubtedly be substantial, with a significant premium over the current market value. Google would need to incentivize HubSpot to sell, as merging with the search giant would be a considerable shift. The two companies already have a partnership, using Google ads to fuel HubSpot sales, which can sometimes pave the way for acquisition discussions.

Google has been consistently active in making acquisitions, with its most significant deal being the $12.5 billion purchase of Motorola Mobility in 2011, later sold to Lenovo for $2.91 billion. A more recent large acquisition was spending $5.4 billion for Mandiant in 2022. However, Google typically prefers deals under $3 billion, making this potential acquisition unusual for the company.

In addition, the tech industry has seen recent austerity programs and job cuts. Google CEO Sundar Pichai warned of upcoming job cuts in January, making such a significant acquisition seem unlikely in the current climate. Nonetheless, with a cash reserve of $110 billion as of the end of last year, Google has the financial means to proceed with the acquisition.

Another challenge facing Google in acquiring HubSpot is the hostile regulatory environment for large deals. Regulators in the U.S., U.K., and E.U. have been closely monitoring significant deals, with some, like Adobe's attempt to buy Figma for $20 billion, falling through due to competitive concerns. Although HubSpot faces stiff competition from Adobe and Salesforce, adding it to Google's portfolio would not provide a monopoly in the CRM market, it might still face regulatory hurdles and associated termination fees.

The primary question is the likelihood of the deal and what benefits it would offer both companies beyond their existing partnership. According to one analyst, the deal doesn't seem probable, but one can never be certain.

Title: A Revolutionary Low-Power Phase Change Memory Device: The Future of Neuromorphic Computing

Introduction

In a remarkable breakthrough, a team of Korean researchers led by Professor Shinhyun Choi at the KAIST School of Electrical Engineering has developed a groundbreaking next-generation phase change memory (PCRAM) device. This novel device boasts ultra-low power consumption, offering a promising solution to the existing limitations of current memory technologies, such as DRAM and NAND flash memory. This article will delve into the structure, operation, and benefits of this new PCRAM device, as well as its implications for the future of artificial intelligence (AI) hardware and neuromorphic computing.

Understanding the NFPCM: Structure and Operation

The novel filamentary PCRAM (NFPCM) device consists of a highly confined BEC (Bose-Einstein condensate) to reduce the reset current, ensuring ultra-low power consumption. The forming process, as well as the set and reset operations, involve the electrical formation of a tiny nanometer (nm) scale phase changeable filament, eliminating the need for expensive fabrication processes (Park et al., 2024). The NFPCM combines the advantages of both DRAM and NAND flash memory, offering high speed and non-volatile characteristics, which makes it an ideal candidate for next-generation memory technology.

Title: A Major Leap Towards Practical Quantum Computing: Microsoft and Quantinuum's Error-Free System

Introduction

The realm of quantum computing has long been a fascinating frontier, with the potential to revolutionize how we approach complex calculations. Traditional computers, limited by classical physics, may soon be outperformed by quantum computers, which could process information exponentially faster using quantum bits or "qubits." Despite announcements of quantum computing hardware by IBM, Google, and others, practical applications have remained elusive due to qubits' susceptibility to errors. However, Microsoft and Quantinuum's latest collaboration aims to change this by unveiling the most accurate quantum computing system to date.

The Quantum Leap

In classical computers, binary bits serve as the fundamental unit of information, representing either an on or off state. Quantum computers, on the other hand, utilize qubits, which can maintain a superposition of two states simultaneously. The challenge with qubits is their inherent error-prone nature, which has limited today's quantum computers (Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum or NISQ computers) to research and experimentation purposes.

Microsoft's novel approach involves bundling physical qubits into virtual qubits, enabling error diagnostics and correction without destroying them. By leveraging Quantinuum's hardware, they achieved an error rate 800 times lower than relying on physical qubits alone, claiming over 14,000 error-free experiments.

The Path to Practical Applications

Jason Zander, EVP of Microsoft's Strategic Missions and Technologies division, believes this milestone brings us closer to "Level 2 Resilient" quantum computing. This reliability could unlock practical applications, transitioning from physical qubits to logical qubits, which combine multiple qubits to protect against noise and sustain long computations.

Professor Aram Harrow, an MIT physicist specializing in quantum information and computing, considers Microsoft's achievement a "strong result." He noted, "The Quantinuum system has impressive error rates and control, so it was plausible that they could do an experiment like this, but it's encouraging to see that it worked." He also expressed hope that the error rate would be maintained or improved as the system scales up.

Title: Google's Potential Shift: A Paywall for Generative AI Features in Search

Google, the search engine titan, has long held the dominant position in the market. However, with the emergence of new generative AI models threatening to disrupt its stronghold, Google is contemplating a seismic shift in its business model.

A recent report by the Financial Times, citing insider sources, revealed that Google is considering introducing a paywall for premium generative AI features in its search engine. This move would see these advanced AI-powered search features being added to Google's premium subscription service, Google One, which was introduced in February.

Engineers are currently working on the technology to implement the model, but Google executives have yet to make a final decision on when, or indeed if, the paywall will be introduced. The Google One plan, priced at $20 per month, offers users access to Gemini for Workspace (previously known as Duet AI), which integrates Google's AI assistance throughout its productivity apps, such as Gmail, Docs, Sheets, Slides, and Meet.

In addition to the AI features, the Google One plan includes other perks like 2TB of storage, Google Photos editing features, 10% back in Google Store rewards, Google Meet premium video calling features, and Google Calendar enhanced appointment scheduling. Google's traditional search engine would continue to remain free and ad-supported.

However, the introduction of a paid search tier represents a significant departure from Google's long-standing business model, which has kept its search engine free since its inception over two decades ago. The question remains: why start charging for search now? The cost of deploying and maintaining generative AI features on its search engine is undoubtedly high. But, whether users would be willing to pay for such an AI-assisted search service, especially when there are numerous free alternatives available, remains to be seen.
